awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High-Density Non-Fouling Bioactive Coatings for Processing of Biological Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER 1553183 - Schilke

Bacterial sepsis is a common and life-threatening condition which kills hundreds of thousands of Americans and costs ~$20 billion every year in the U.S. alone. Sepsis is currently treated with antibiotics, but this does not remove the circulating dead bacteria and fragments of their cell membranes (endotoxin), which could cause a serious immune response. One promising method to mitigate this risk involves passing a patient's blood through a device to capture circulating endotoxin, helping to stabilize the immune system and potentially to improve their prognosis. However for this application, all materials in contact with blood must be biocompatible (i.e. resist fouling or clotting, and not induce an adverse biological response). For treatment of sepsis, surfaces must also present endotoxin-binding agents in controlled orientations and at high density. These bioactive and biocompatible coatings must be inexpensive and easy to apply to a wide range of materials, including plastics used in medical devices, needles, flexible tubing, and other associated equipment. Biocompatible and bioactive coatings could have transformative impact on the safety and efficacy of treatment of sepsis, in which even a modest improvement could result in many lives and much money saved. In other biomedical applications, the technology could also impart biological activity to a variety of other household, consumer and industrial products. The integrated educational activities of this project are expected to achieve the following benefits: (a) research concepts will be incorporated into bioengineering coursework at Oregon State (OSU) and hands-on learning modules will be adapted for OSU's STEM Academy for pre-college students and (b) the PI will work with the OSU business school to provide a summer "Entrepreneurship Boot Camp" for the group's graduate students and faculty mentors.

The project's research will result in the development of high-density, non-fouling bioactive coatings (HNB's) by living polymerization from surfactant-based immobilized initiators, producing branched, hydrophilic polymer brushes on the surface. This coating, essentially an ultrathin immobilized hydrogel, will provide excellent resistance against protein adsorption and cell interactions (biocompatibility). To impart bioactivity at the hydrogel surface, a nearly-ideal bioorthogonal ligation (BOL) will be used to immobilize enzymes, peptides, polysaccharides, or other biologically active molecules at the periphery of the brush. This chemistry enables quantitative conjugation from even dilute solutions of the active molecule, allowing precise control of surface functionalization. Unreacted groups are biologically compatible and chemically inert. Economical immobilization of peptides or proteins is provided by Genetic Code Expansion (GCE), in which engineered microbes express active proteins with BOL reactive groups incorporated at genetically-controlled positions. The resulting specific immobilization of only the desired proteins from a crude cell lysate eliminates costly purification or pre-concentration steps, and guarantees that the protein is in a precisely defined orientation for maximal biological activity. Although the main objective of this work is to demonstrate biocompatible and bioactive coatings for devices to capture pathogens from blood, myriad other potential uses include safer medical devices, food processing, pharmaceutical production, active packaging, and self-cleaning fabrics, as examples.

por.por_cntn:
Background and Motivation:

 

Blood-contacting materials must often resist fouling or clotting. It is also often desirable to impart biological activity (e.g. antimicrobial, pathogen binding, chelation, enzyme, etc.) by immobilizing proteins or other molecules at the surface. Efficient biological activity of the bound molecules usually depends on their specific molecular orientation and a high surface density.  Such bioactive and biocompatible coatings must further be inexpensive, safe, and easy to apply to a wide range of materials, including plastics used in medical devices, needles, flexible tubing, etc.

 

Conventional immobilization requires chemical activation of solid surfaces using various reagents, which must be tailored to the material and are often hazardous and expensive. Most standard immobilization approaches are relatively non-specific and will bind any protein in a mixture, so the desired bioactive proteins must be highly purified in expensive upstream processes. Finally, proteins may not be bound "right side up," limiting bioactivity at the surface.

 

We aimed to address both issues through "selectively fouling" nanoscale coatings, which would repel non-specific adsorption of cells and biomolecules (biocompatibility) while simultaneously immobilizing the proteins or other molecules that impact the desired bioactivity.

 

 

Experimental Approach:

 

Hyperbranched Polymers:

We used surface-initiated atom-transfer radical polymerization (SI-ATRP) to create linear and highly branched hydrophilic polymer brush layers on surfaces. We produced branched neutral poly[hydroxyethyl methacrylate], and linear charged poly(aminopropyl methacrylate) and zwitterionic poly(sulfobetaine methacrylate). Placing initiator (-Br) groups on surfaces using end-group activated triblock surfactants or conventional chemistries (e.g. bromosilane) was successful. However, we switched to the simpler, more universal poly(dopamine) system, a biomimetic polymer like that used by mussels to attach to marine surfaces. Small molecules with both initiator and monomer groups (inimers) were added to create branch points. The result is a highly interpenetrating, nanoscale polymer hydrogel that is anchored at numerous initiator sites.

 

The -Br atom on initiators is transferred to the end of the polymer chains during polymerization, and can be converted easily to a terminal azide (-N3). Highly specific, rapid 'click' reaction between these azides and an alkyne (-C≡C-) can be used to covalently attach alkyne-containing molecules to the polymer ends. Azides and alkynes are not present in natural proteins and are essentially inert. These click reactions are thus biorthogonal, and should enable targeted and specific immobilization of desired proteins from a complex mixture (e.g. blood, cell lysate)

 

Expression of Click-Ready Proteins:

 

Genetic code expansion (GCE) enables the substitution of natural amino acids (AAs) by non-canonical, synthetic (ncAAs) during protein expression. The location of the ncAA is precisely controlled by genetic constructs. We used GCE to successfully express a small lytic tail spike protein, Abc2, from bacteriophage P22 with individual substitutions of the click-ready ncAA p-azidophenylalanine (pAzF) for surface amino acids (Asn17, Arg58, or Leu81). We attached Abc2 via click reaction to immobilized alkyne-terminated PEO-PPO-PEO (F108) surfactants.  We then demonstrated capture of bacterial endotoxin (which can cause sepsis) by the immobilized phage protein. Endotoxin capture was strongly dependent on the location of the ncAA substitution.

 

We also expressed a hyperthermophilic beta-glucosidase (Bgplf) from Pyrococcus furiosus, with surface amino acid substitutions (D66, E116, or K392) with click-ready azide (pAzF) or alkyne-containing ncAAs (p-ethynylphenylalanine; pEnF). Enzymatic activity and Michaelis-Menten coefficients strongly depended on the location of substitution. Expression of pEnF-glucosidase was troublesome. Expression yield was low, presumably because the GCE 'machinery' was optimized for p-cyano-phenylalanine instead of pEnF. Click reactions with pEnF, alone or on the protein, were also unsuccessful despite the verified presence of the ncAA.

 

 

Outcomes and Conclusions

 

We demonstrated surface-initiated synthesis of linear and hyperbranched polymer brushes, from initiators based on small molecules, novel triblock surfactants, and brominated biomimetic polydopamine layers.

 

We successfully expressed a phage protein (Abc2) and bacterial enzyme (Bgplf), each with pAzF substitutions at three surface sites.  We also expressed Bgplf with pEnF substitutions, but yields were low and results were poor. Further troubleshooting of the pEnF-Bgplf model system is warranted.

 

Endotoxin binding activity by Abc2 and enzymatic activity of Bgplf both strongly depended on the location of ncAA substitution. This suggests that molecular orientation is critical to optimal activity, especially when proteins are immobilized.

 

The global COVID-19 pandemic and shutdown arrived during the first month of the final year of the project. Due to lab access and staffing issues, including the PI's unexpected medical retirement, we were unable to demonstrate the final goal: Rapid and specific immobilization of target proteins from a crude lysate or blood.

Further work to demonstrate this goal is warranted, as it could reduce expensive pre-purification of target proteins prior to immobilization. Other applications might include active packaging, diagnostics and lab-on-chip devices, biosensors, etc.
